msItem.title: Gloriosa dicta sunt de te
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.textLang: Middle English poem with a reference to a Latin title
msItem.rubric: 1 Loo my freendes here beginneþe þe translacyoune out of latyne in to englisshe of Gloriosa dicta sunt de te etcaetera translated by Lidegate daun Iohn þe Munk of Bury at þinstaunce of þe Busshop of excestre in Wyse of Balade beholdeþe and redeþe I prey yowe
msItem.incipit: 1 On hooly hilles wheeche beoþe of gret Renoun / Reysed on heght frome þe valeys lowe / I saughe þe grounde and þe foundacioun / Of a Cyte aboue þe Reynebowe
msItem.explicit: 8 Whane we passe hens by mercy make vs dwelle / Where gloryous thinges [DIMEV: glory and thinges] be sayde and song of þee
msItem.note: Added titles in the upper margins: Balade of our ladye by Lidegate; A glorious songe by lydegate made of ourse blessed ladye; Devoute songe made by lydegate of oure ladye.

msItem.title: Four things that make a man a fool
msItem.author: John Lydgate (attributed)
msItem.rubric: 8A seyng of dan Iohn lydgat
msItem.incipit: 8 Þere beoþe foure thinges þat makeþ man a fool / Honnour first putteþe him in oultrage / And aldernexst solytarye and sool / Þe secound is vnweldy crooked aage
msItem.explicit: 9 And mighty wyne in many dyuers wyse / Distempren folk wheche been holden wyse
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margins: Proverbes.

msItem.title: Four things that make man a fool
msItem.author: John Lydgate (attributed)
msItem.rubric: 9 Yit of þe same
msItem.incipit: 9 þer beon foure thinges causing gret folye / Honnour first and vnweldy aage / Wymmen an wyne I dare eeke specefye / Make wyse men fallen in dotage
msItem.explicit: 9 In gret honnour lerne þis of me / With þyne estate haue humylytee
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margin: Proverbes.

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.author: John Lydgate (attributed)
msItem.rubric: 9 Prouerbe
msItem.incipit: 9 Subtilis duplicitas - Italicorum / Manifesta luxuria - Theotonicorum
msItem.explicit: 9 Effrenata superbia - Gallicorum / Rara ffidelitas - Anglicorum
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margin: Proverbes.

msItem.title: Favourable and unfavourable days for bloodletting
msItem.author: Bede the Venerable (attributed)
msItem.rubric: 9 Ceste le dit de saynt Beede
msItem.incipit: 9 Il est assavoir que troys jours sount en l'an en queaux si homme seygne ou medecyne prent il mourera dainz le mesme an certagnement
msItem.explicit: 9 certaynement ceo est assauoir le derrain Jour danvyll / Le primer Jour daugst et le derrain Jour de decembre
msItem.note: Full transcription. Perhaps derived from Bede's De minutione sanguinis, sive De phlebotomia.

msItem.title: Dictum de senioribus
msItem.rubric: 9 Dictum de senioribus
msItem.incipit: 9 Italici Vlilant - Lombardes weymenten / Theotonici Clamant - Duchemen cryen / Gallici Cantant - ffrenshmen singen / Anglicis Jubilant - And Englisshmen Joyessen = Videte
msItem.note: DIMEV mistranscribes: Italicis, Theotonicis, Gallicis, Anglicis for the nominative plurals of these nouns; and Olilant for Vlilant and subilant for jubilant.
Full transcription. Added title in the upper margin: Proverbes.

msItem.title: 'Bycorne and Chychevache'
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 10 Loo sirs þe deuise of a peynted or desteynede clothe for an halle a parlour or a chaumbre deuysed by Iohan Lidegate at þe request of a worþy citeseyn of London ffirst þere shal stonde an ymage in poete wyse seying þees thre balades
msItem.incipit: 10 O prudent folkes takeþe heed / And Remembreþe in youre lyves / Howe þis story doþe proceed / Of þe housbandes and þeyre wyves
msItem.explicit: 15 Of lyff and deeth bytwix tweyne / Lynkeld in a double cheyne
msItem.note: Added titles in the upper margins: Þe fourome of desguysinges contreved by daun Johan Lidegate; Þe maner of straunge desysingee; and Þe gyse of a Mournynge.

msItem.title: 'A wikked tong wol alway deme amis'
msItem.author: John Lydgate (here attributed)
msItem.rubric: 15 Lo my lordes here begynneþe a balade of gode counseyle translated out of verses in latyn in to englisshe by daun Johan þe Monk of Bury cleped Lydegate
msItem.incipit: 15 Considere weel with euery circumstaunce / Of what estate euer þat þou be / Ryche stronge or mighty of puissaunce / Prudent or wyse discreet or avysee
msItem.explicit: 19 Chastyseþe þe reuers of wisdame depe þis / Woydeþe your hering frome all þat deeme amysse
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margins: A morale balade made by Lidegate.

msItem.title: Paraphrase of Psalm 102 ('Benedic anima mea')
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.textLang: Middle English with Latin in rubrics
msItem.rubric: 19 Takeþe goode heed sirs and dames howe Lydegate daun Johan þe Munk of Bury moeued of deuocyoun haþe translated þe salme Benedic anima mea domino
msItem.incipit: 19-20 O þou my soule gyf laude vn to þe lord / Blesse him and preyse and forget him nought / Alle myn entrayllis booþe in deed and word / And al þat euer is in myn inward thought
msItem.explicit: 25 Asseele oure quytaunce with þy redempcion / Whane þou shalt deme vs stonding to fore þy face
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margins: Translacioun by Lidegate of þe salme Bendic anima mea domino.
This is the first occurence of Lydgate's paraphrase of Psalm 102 in this manuscript; see also pp. 165-171.

msItem.title: 'Doye Je chauntier plourier ou ryre'
msItem.author: William de la Pole
msItem.textLang: Middle French poem with a Middle English rubric
msItem.rubric: 25 Here begynnepe A Roundell which my lord of Suffolk made affter his comyng oute of prysoune
msItem.incipit: 25 Doye Je chauntier plourier ou ryre
msItem.explicit: 25 Tant que mon male plus empire

msItem.title: Thoroughfare of Woe
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 25 And here filowing begynneþe a balade of goode counseyle made by Lydegate daune Johan looke and reede
msItem.incipit: 26 Lyfft vp þe eyeghen of youre aduertence / Yee þat beon blynde with worldely vanyte
msItem.explicit: 32 Declared truwly and list not for to feyne / Howe þis worlde is a thorughfare ful of woo
msItem.note: Added titlte in the upper margins: Balade ful comendable made by Lidegate.

msItem.title: 'Lealement a tous jours mais'
msItem.author: Alain Chartier [William de la Pole, attributed]
msItem.textLang: Middle French poem with a Middle English rubric
msItem.rubric: 32 Loo here bygynneþe a Rondell made by my lord of Suffolk wylest he was prysonnier in ffraunce
msItem.incipit: 32 Lealement a tous Jours mais
msItem.explicit: 32 Si serrount noz playsirs parfais
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margin: Roundelles of frenshe.

msItem.title: 'Face vo coer tout ce que ly plera'
msItem.author: William de la Pole (attributed)
msItem.textLang: Middle French poem with a Middle English rubric
msItem.rubric: 33 Yit filoweþe here anoþer Roundell of my lordes / making of Suffolk whyles he was prisonier in ffraunce
msItem.incipit: 33 fface vo coer tout ce que ly plera
msItem.explicit: 33 Tiel demouray sans pensir ca ne la
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margin: Roundell of ffrenshe.

msItem.title: 'Puis qualer vers vous ne puisse'
msItem.author: William de la Pole (attributed)
msItem.incipit: v Puis qualer vers vous ne puisse
msItem.explicit: 33 Je vous Requere tant que Je puis
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margin: Roundell off ffrenshe.

msItem.title: 'Ballade of her that hath all virtues'
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 34 Loo here begynneþe a Balade whiche þat Lydegate wrote at þe request of a squyer þat serued in loves court
msItem.incipit: 34 ffresshe lusty beaute Joyned with gentylesse / Demure appert glad chere with gouernaunce
msItem.explicit: 35 Truwly to hir to done my message which haþe alle vertues sette in hir ymage
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margins: Balade of Love by sir Othes of holand.

msItem.title: 'Je vous salue ma maystresse'
msItem.author: William de la Pole
msItem.rubric: 35 Ycy comence vn balade que fist monseignur le Conte de Suffolk quant il estoit prysonier en ffraunce
msItem.incipit: 35 Je vous salue ma maystresse
msItem.explicit: 36 Et me fit vostre sy mait dieu
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margins: Roundel and balade of love.
Added to the rubric is a note in the hand of John Stow (1524/5-1605), identifying the Duke of Suffolk as William dela Poole.

msItem.title: 'Quel desplaysier, quel courous, quel destresse'
msItem.author: William de la Pole
msItem.textLang: Middle French poem with a Middle English rubric
msItem.rubric: 36 And filowing here begynepe a Roundell made be same tyme by my sayde lord perlle of Suffolk
msItem.incipit: 36 Quel desplaysier, quel courous, quel destresse, / Quel grief, quelx mauls viennent souuent damours
msItem.explicit: 36 Puis quen sy va, que Iay tous le Rebours / De mon plaisir, Ie ne quier que tristesse
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margins: Roundel and balade of love.

msItem.title: 'Dieux nous dona petit de vie'
msItem.author: Eustache Deschamps
msItem.textLang: Middle French poem with a Middle English rubric
msItem.rubric: 36 Here filowepe a Balade made in ffraunce which my lord of Suffolk þeorlle mich allowepe in his witt
msItem.incipit: 37 Dieux nous dona petit de vie
msItem.explicit: 37 ll nest home qui ait point de demain
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margins: Roundel and balade of love.

msItem.title: Mumming at Eltham
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 37 Loo here begynneþe a balade made by daun John Lidegate at Eltham in Cristmasse for a momyng to fore þe Kyng and þe Qwene
msItem.incipit: 38 Bachus which is god of þe glade vyne / Juno and Ceres acorded alle þeos three / Thorughe þeyre power which þat is devyne / Sende nowe þeyre gifftes vn to your magestee
msItem.explicit: 40 To you pryncesse al so yif yee aduerte / Ay be encresse Ioye gladdnesse of herte
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margins: þe maner of a mommynge To fore þe Kynge at Elthame.

msItem.title: Mumming at Hertford [Disguising at Hertford]
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 40 Nowe foloweþe here þe manere of a bille by wey of supplicacioun putte to þe Kyng holding his noble feest of Cristmasse in þe Castel of Hertford as in a disguysing of þe Pride Vpplandisshe people compleyning on hir wyves with þe boystous aunswere of hir wyves devysed by lydegate at þe Request of þe Counte Roullour [added by another hand: Brys slayne at Loviers]
msItem.incipit: 40 Moost noble prynce with support of your grace / Þer been entred in to youre royal place / And late coomen in to youre castell / Youre poure lieges wheche lyke no thing weel
msItem.explicit: 48 Þoughe þat his prysoun his castell or his holde / Wer depeynted with asure or with golde
msItem.note: Added titles to the upper margins: A desguysing to fore þe kyng In cristemasse In þe castell of Hertford and A desgisinge to fore þe Kynge and qweene.

msItem.title: 'Balade de bone counseyle'
msItem.rubric: 48 Balade de bone counseyle
msItem.incipit: 48 Yif hit befalle þat god þes list visyte With any tourment or Aduersytee
msItem.explicit: 48 Make þy defence and þou shalt haue no losseþe Remembrasunce of Cryst and of his crosse

msItem.title: 'Ronde toy a quoy tu le sauras'
msItem.author: Eustache Deschamps
msItem.textLang: Middle French poem with a Middle English rubric
msItem.rubric: 48 A balade of frenshe drawing man to þe right wey
msItem.incipit: 49 Ronde toy a quoy tu le sauras
msItem.explicit: 49 Quar je ne scey meilleur trouver

msItem.title: 'Le mounde va en amendaunt'
msItem.rubric: 49 Icy comence vn balade ffrauncoys fait par le plus grande poetycal Clerk du parys regardez et lysez - Je vous en pry
msItem.incipit: 49 Le mounde va en amendaunt
msItem.explicit: 50 Aynsi come le Cravisse va

msItem.title: ‘Riȝt as the crabbe goth forward’
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 50 Takeþe heede my lordes for here foloweþe a balade of þe same sentence made in oure englisshe langage by daun Johan Lidegate of Bury þe Munke noue Iugeþe yee þat beoþe kunyng which yowe lykeþe þe beter þe ffrensh or þenglissh
msItem.incipit: 50-51 Þis worlde is ful of stabulnesse / þer is þer Inne no varyaunce / But trouthe feyth and gentylesse / Secrenesse and assuraunce
msItem.explicit: 52 Howe þat þe Crabbe gooþe bakward / Þe hevenly signe makeþe demonstraunce

msItem.title: 'Qui veult son corps en santé maintenir'
msItem.author: Eustache Dechamps
msItem.rubric: 52 Vescy vn honnourable balade ffrancoys du regyment du corps
msItem.incipit: v Qui veult son corps en santé maintenir
msItem.explicit: 53 Et ne va hors sy ne fait bel et cler
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: þe desgysing Balade of frenshe.

msItem.title: Gaude virgo mater Christi
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 53 Beholdeþe nowe filowing nexst here þe translacyoune of Gaude virgo mater Christi made by daun Johan þe Munke Lydegate by night as he lay in his bedde at London
msItem.incipit: 53 Be gladde mayde moder of Cryst Ihesu / Whiche conceyvedist oonly by hering / Whane þoohely gooste moost souereyn of vertu / Entred þy brest frome heven descending
msItem.explicit: 55 Where with þy sone þou regnest in gladnesse / Oonly of mercy and stynt oure hevynesse
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balade of Gaude virgo mater Christi made by Lidegate.

msItem.title: Mumming at London
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 55 Lo here filoweþe þe deuyse of a desguysing to fore þe gret estates of þis lande þane being at London madeby Lidegate daun Johan þe Munk of Bury of dame fortune dame proudence dame Rightwysnesse and dame ffortitudo beholdeþe for it is moral plesaunt and notable. Loo first komeþe in dame ffortune
msItem.incipit: 55 Loo here þis lady þat yee may see / Lady of mutabilitee
msItem.explicit: 65 Suche oon as þou lykeþe best / Lat ffortune go pley hir wher hir list
msItem.note: Added rubric to the text: Explicit; and added title to the upper margins: A desguysing made by Lydegate of þe foure Cardynale vertues.

msItem.title: Anti-feminist poem on marriage
msItem.rubric: 65 Hic incipit quedam disputacio in consilio nubendi
msItem.incipit: 65 Sit deo gloria laus et benedicio / Johanni pariter . Petro . Laurencio / Quos misit Trinitas in hoc naufragio / Ne me permitterent vti coniugio
msItem.explicit: 70-71 Ingressus tartari Sunt viro nuptie / Ibi est mulier In loco furie / Nati qui deuorant Sunt qua et bestie / Pene defficiles Et multipharie
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: A counseyle howe to bee wedded.

msItem.title: Mumming at Windsor
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 71 Nowe foloweþe nexst þe devyse of a momyng to fore þe Kyng Henry þe sixte being in his Castell of Wyndesore þe fest of his crystmasse holding þer made by lidegate daun Johan þe munk of Bury howe þampull and þe floure delys came first to þe Kynges of ffraunce by myrakle at Reynes
msItem.incipit: 71 Moost noble prynce of Cristen prynces alle / To youre hyeghnesse lat hit bee plesaunce / In youre presence men may to mynde calle / How þat whylom ȝoure worthy Reavme of ffraunce
msItem.explicit: 74 Lyst to supporte here sitting in þy see / Right as it fell þis myracle to see
msItem.note: Added titles to the upper margins: Howe þampoule and þe floure delyce came to þe Kynges of ffraunce and Of þe Ampoull And þe floure delyce.

msItem.title: Legend of St George
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 74 Nexst nowe filowing here bygynneþe þe devyse of a steyned halle of þe lyf of saint George ymagyned by daun Iohan þe Munk of Bury Lydegate and made with þe balade at þe request of þarmorieres of london for þonour of þeyre broþerhoode and þeyre feest of saint George - þee poete first declareþe
msItem.incipit: 74 O yee folk þat heer present be / Wheeche of þis story shal haue Inspeccioun / Of saint George yee may beholde and see / His martirdome and his passyoun
msItem.explicit: 81 Was brent vnwarly by consumpcyoun / As he repayred hoome to his mansyoun
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: A Storye of Saint George.

msItem.title: 'Celuy qui dit en deaux mos gracyeux'
msItem.rubric: 81 Balade fait a parys quant les burgoygnouns bouterount hors les armynaux
msItem.incipit: 81 Celuy quy dit en deaux mos gracyeux
msItem.explicit: 82 Puis que Paris a la teste levee

msItem.title: Solomon and Marcolf
msItem.rubric: 82 Veez cy vne desputacioun entre Salamon ly saage et Marcoulf le foole
msItem.incipit: 82 Salamon dit: Mortalité et guerre / Fount exil de terre / Et destruizemens
msItem.explicit: 86 Marcoulf responnt: Que tient en sa main / la foy du putain / moult a maulvais gage
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Of Salamon þe wyse and Marcolf þe more foole.

msItem.title: Dits et proverbes des philosophes ['Proverbs de les xvij sages']
msItem.rubric: 86 Ceaux sount les prouerbes rymeyez en francoys . de les .xvij. sages que cy ensuyent
msItem.incipit: 86 Platon dit : Joesnes homes qui vist en cremour
msItem.explicit: 88 Qui ne mysent cynk [?] anemys
msItem.note: Added titles to the upper margins: þe Proverbes of þe Wyse men and Proverbes of Wysemen.

msItem.title: 'Je vous prie tant come je puisse'
msItem.rubric: 89 Roundell dune belle dame
msItem.incipit: 89 Je vous prie tant come je puisse
msItem.explicit: 89 Quant de ma part tant vous en dis

msItem.title: 'Tant de perilz sont a suir la court'
msItem.author: Eustache Deschamps
msItem.rubric: 89 Balade de bone counselle
msItem.incipit: 89 Tant de perilz sont a suir la court
msItem.explicit: 89 Dauoir on court l'un pie hors et l'autre ens
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margin: Balade de bone conseyle.

msItem.title: 'Je voy le temps Otouien'
msItem.author: Eustache Deschamps
msItem.rubric: 90 Balade bon et notable
msItem.incipit: 90 Je voy le temps Otouien
msItem.explicit: 90 Dit il vray par ma foy il ment
msItem.note: Ends with the note: Veycy balade selonc le mounde qui courte maintenant.

msItem.title: 'Qui ces besoignes veult bien faire'
msItem.author: Eustache Deschamps
msItem.incipit: 91 Qui ces besoignes veult bien faire
msItem.explicit: 91 Mon seigneur dit [bn] il a droit
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margin: Balade Notable.

msItem.title: 'Les biens mondaine et toulx les accessoires'
msItem.author: Christine de Pizan
msItem.rubric: 91 Balade ryal de sauie counseylle
msItem.incipit: 91 Les biens mondaine et toulx les accessoires
msItem.explicit: 92 Auisons nous Il nous coment mourir
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balade Notable.

msItem.title: 'Puis que je suy fumeux plain du fumee'
msItem.author: Eustache Deschamps
msItem.rubric: 92 Balade de bone sentence fait pour le meystrye
msItem.incipit: 92 Puis que je suy fumeux plain du fumee
msItem.explicit: 93 Quant on fume sans se altruy dommage
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balade Notable.

msItem.title: 'Amours est bien par son nom appelez'
msItem.author: Eustache Deschamps
msItem.rubric: 93 Balade counseyllent les amans
msItem.incipit: 93 Amours est bien par son nom appelez
msItem.explicit: 94 On luy respont encor nest Il pas temps
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margin: Balade of ffrenshe.

msItem.title: 'Ma doulce amour et dame souueraine'
msItem.author: Eustache Deschamps
msItem.rubric: 94 Balade moult bone et ryal
msItem.incipit: 94 Ma doulce amour et dame souueraine
msItem.explicit: 95 Et loyaulte tenir ou que je soy
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margin: Right playsaunte.

msItem.title: 'Vous me priez sy amoureusement'
msItem.author: Eustache Deschamps
msItem.rubric: 95 La respounce sage et moult courtoyse
msItem.incipit: 95 Vous me priez sy amoureusement
msItem.explicit: 96 Je vous respons que je m'aviseray
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margin: Balades Amorous of frenshe.

msItem.title: 'Je me merveil du desir que mesprent'
msItem.rubric: 96 Tresbone balade amoreux
msItem.incipit: 96 Je me merveil du desir que mesprent
msItem.explicit: 97 Je la regart et n'ose dire rien
msItem.note: Added titles to the upper margins: Balades Amorous of frenshe and Gracyous.

msItem.title: 'Puisque desir me fait estre amoreux'
msItem.rubric: 97 Balade gaye et gracyeux
msItem.incipit: 97 Puisque desir me fait estre amoreux
msItem.explicit: 98 Dieu la parfit pour abellir le monde

msItem.title: 'A vous dame humblement me complains'
msItem.rubric: 98 Balade que fist faire le duc de Bavier
msItem.incipit: 98 A vous dame humblement me complains
msItem.explicit: 98 Vray corps gentilz pour vostre amour mourray
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margin: Balades tresbones.

msItem.title: 'Vous qui fuistes en jeunesse moult cointe'
msItem.rubric: 99 Balade merveylleuse
msItem.incipit: 99 Vous qui fuistes en jeunesse moult cointe
msItem.explicit: 99 D'amer aultruy ne d'aultruy estre amee

msItem.title: 'J'ay frequente maint compaignon galant'
msItem.rubric: 99 Balade morale apren le
msItem.incipit: 99 J'ay frequente maint compaignon galant
msItem.explicit: 100 Alez a Dieu quar gales sont failliez
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balades ffrauncoys.

msItem.title: 'J'ay veu et haute longement'
msItem.rubric: 100 Balade moult veritables - Regardez
msItem.incipit: 100 J'ay veu et haute longement
msItem.explicit: 101 Nulle n'est prisie s'il n'ait chevance
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balades ffrauncoys.

msItem.title: 'On parle de maladie'
msItem.rubric: 101 Balade moult bon a sauoir
msItem.incipit: 101 On parle de maladie
msItem.explicit: 102 Il n'est rage que d'avoir fain
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balades ffrauncoys.

msItem.title: 'Je fortune de ce mounde a emperier'
msItem.rubric: 102 Balade bone a regarder
msItem.incipit: 102 Je fortune de ce mounde a emperier
msItem.explicit: 102 Car tot ou tarde compter fault qui recoit
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balades ffrauncoys.

msItem.title: 'Que vault tresor qui na joye ne leesse'
msItem.rubric: 103 Balade moral et de bone counseylle
msItem.incipit: 103 Que vault tresor qui na joye ne leesse
msItem.explicit: 103 Qui plus aura plus dolent mourra
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balades ffrauncoys.

msItem.title: 'Je voy les estas amender'
msItem.rubric: 103 Balade credible tout a rebours de les mos
msItem.incipit: 103 Je voy les estas amender
msItem.explicit: 104 Par saint Mor c'est tout a rebours
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balades ffrauncoys.

msItem.title: 'Que fais tu Clerk que veux tu que je die'
msItem.rubric: 105 Balade voulgare
msItem.incipit: 105 Que fais tu Clerk que veux tu que je die
msItem.explicit: 106 Me dieu voir oil sainte Marie
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balades ffrauncoys.

msItem.title: The Compleynt of Anelida the quene upon fals Arcite (extract from Anelida and Arcite)
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 106 Takeþe heed sirs I prey yowe of þis compleynt of Anelyda Qweene of Cartage Roote of trouthe and stedfastnesse þat pytously compleyneþe vpon þe varyance of daun Arcyte lord borne of þe blood Royal of Thebes englisshed by Geffrey Chaucier in þe best wyse and moost Rethoricyous þe moost vnkouþe metre coloures and Rymes þat euer was sayde tofore þis day redeþe and preveþe þe sooþe
msItem.incipit: 106 So thirlleþe with þe poynt of Remembraunce / Þe swerd of sorowe whett with fals plesaunce
msItem.explicit: 110 Howe þat Arcyte Anelyda so soore / Haþe thirlled with þe point of Remembraunce
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: þe Compleynte of Anelyda.

msItem.title: 'A Holy Meditation' [possibly Geoffrey Chaucer's Wretched Engendering]
msItem.author: ? Geoffrey Chaucer; ? John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 111 Nowe here filoweþe an holy medytacioun
msItem.incipit: 111 Affter þe stormy tyme cessing þe rayn / Whane for þabsence of colde þeorþe is fayn / And þe qwyck thinges resceyue vygour / And trees bringen foorþe leef and flour
msItem.explicit: 116 If þou do þus þane shal þy soule weende / To heuene blisse which þat haþe noon eende - Amen
msItem.note: Added titles to the upper margins An holy seying and A devoute Meditacioun.

msItem.title: Letter of Cupid [loose adaptation of Christine de Pizan's Epistre au dieu d'Amours]
msItem.author: Thomas Hoccleve
msItem.rubric: 116 Nowe here filowing beginneþe a lytel traytis made and compyled by Thomas Occleue of þoffice of þe priue seel specifying þe maners and þe conuersacions booþe of men and wymmen conuersantes in þis lytell yle of Albyone
msItem.incipit: 116 Cvpido vn to whas commaundement / þe gentil kynrede of goddes on hye / And people infernal been obedyent / And alle mortel folk serve besely
msItem.explicit: 130 Þe yeere of grace Ioyefull and iocounde / A thousande foure hundreþe yeres and secound
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: A gode Parable made by Occleue.

msItem.title: 'The Complaint of Mars'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 130 Loo yee louers gladeþe and comforteþe þou of þallyaunce creayted bytwene þe hardy and furyous Mars þe god of armes and Venus þe double goddesse of loue made by Geffrey Chaucier at þe commandement of þe renomed and excellent prynce my lord þe duc John of Lancastre
msItem.incipit: 130 Gladeþe yee fooles of þis morowen gray / Loo Venus is vysen amonge youre rowes reede
msItem.explicit: 139 Þat neuer did but al gentylesse / Rydeþe on hir þer fore some sykurnesse
msItem.finalRubric: 139 Þus eondeþe here þis complaint whiche some men sayne was made by my lady of York doughter to þe kyng of Spaygne and my lord of huntyngdon some tyme duk of Excestre
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Þallyance bytwene Mars and Venus .

msItem.title: 'The Complaint of Venus' [from the French of Oton de Graunson]
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 139 and filowing begynneþe a balade translated out of frenshe in to englisshe by Chaicier Geffrey þe frenshe made sir Otes de Grauntsoune knight Savosyen
msItem.incipit: 139 Þer nys so hye counfort to my plesaunce / Whane þat I am in any hevynesse / As for to haue leyser of Remembraunce / Vpon þe manhoode and þe Worþynesse
msItem.explicit: 141 To folowen word y word þe curyosytee / Of Graunsomme flour of hem þat make in ffraunce
msItem.finalRubric: 141 Hit is sayde þat Graunsomme made þis last balade for venus resembled to my lady of york aunswering þe complaynt of Mars
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: A Balade made by Chaucer At þe reverence of a lady þat loved a knyght.

msItem.title: Fortune
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 142 Hit is sayde þat Graunsomme made þis last balade for venus resembled to my lady of york aunswering þe complaynt of Mars and here filoweþe a balade made by Chaucier of þe louer and of dame ffortune
msItem.incipit: 142 Þis wrechched worldes transmutacyoun / As weele and woo nowe poure and nowe honnour / With outen ordir or wyse discrescioun / Gouuerned is by ffortunes hye errour
msItem.explicit: 144 Preyeþe his best freond of his hye noblesse / Þat to some beter estate he may atteyne
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Dialoge bytwene þe lover and fortune.

msItem.title: 'Truth' or 'Ballade de bon conseyl'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 144 Balade þat Chaucier made on his deeth bedde
msItem.incipit: 144 fflee fro þe prees and dwelle with soothfastnesse / Souffyse vn to þy goode þaughe hit be smal
msItem.explicit: 144 Weyve þy loust and let þy gooste þee lede / And trouthe þee shal delyure hit is no dred
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balade ryale by Chaucer.

msItem.title: 'Valentine to Our Lady'
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 145 Lo here beginneþe a balade made at þe reuerence of our lady by daun Iohan Lidegate þe Munke of Bury in wyse of chesing loues at saint Valentynes day
msItem.incipit: 145 Seynt Valentyne of custume yeere by yeere / Men haue an vsaunce in þis Regyoun / To looke and serche Cupydes kalundere / And cheese þeyre choys by gret affeccioun
msItem.explicit: 149 Haue on vs mercy whane we for help calle / ffor loue of hir þat excelleþe alle
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balade for saint Valentynes daye.

msItem.title: Balade on a New Year’s Gift of an Eagle presented to King Henry VI in 1428
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 149 Þis balade was gyven vn to þe Kyng Henry þe vj [þe vj was added by a later hand] and to his moder þe qweene kateryne sittyng at þe mete vpon þe yeris day in þe Castell of Hertford made by Ledegate
msItem.incipit: 149 Þis hardy foole þis bridde victoryous / Þis staately foole mooste Imperyal / Of his nature fiers and corageous / Called in scripture þe foole celestyal
msItem.explicit: 152 And to yow pryncesse he wol also þer be / Helth and welfare Ioye and prosparytee
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balade made to þe Kyng Henry and to þe qwene Kateryne.

msItem.title: 'A Gentlewoman's Lament'
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 152 And here begynneþe a balade sayde by a gentil womman whiche loued a man of gret estate
msItem.incipit: 152 Allas I wooful creature / Lyving betweene hope and dreed / Howe might I þe woo endure / In tendrenesse of wommanhede
msItem.explicit: 154 To haue hooly my Remembraunce / On his persone so mychil I thynke
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: A Womans Compleynte made by Lidegate.

msItem.title: Ballade to King Henry VI upon his Coronation
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 154 Loo here filowing beginneþ a balade whiche daun Johan Lidegate þe Munk of Bury made vn to þe Kyng þis Iune yeere of his coronacion
msItem.incipit: 154 Moost noble Prynce of cristin prynces alle / fflouring in youþe and vertuous Innocence / Whome god aboue lift of his grace calle / Þis day testaate of knyghtly excellence
msItem.explicit: 158 And god shal sende frome þe heven adoun / Grace and goode hure vn to þy Royale state
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balade of þe Kynges Coronacion.

msItem.title: On the Duke of Gloucester's approaching marriage to Jacqueline of Hainault
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 158 And nowe here begynneþe a comendable balade by Lydegate daun Johan at þe reuerence of my lady of holand and of my lord of Gloucestre to fore þe day of þeyre maryage in þe desyrous tyme of þeyre trewe lovyng
msItem.incipit: 158 Thorugh gladde aspectis of þe god Cupyde / And ful acorde of his moder deere / ffull offt syþes list aforne provyde / By cours eterne of þe sterres cleere
msItem.explicit: 164 Sith I it made bytwix hope and dreed / Of hoole entent yowe for tyl do plesaunce
msItem.finalRubric: 164 And þus eendeþe heere þis balade and filowing begynneþe
msItem.note: Added titlte to the upper margins: Of my lord of Gloucestre and of my Ladye of Holand.

msItem.title: Paraphrase of Psalm 102 ('Benedic anima mea domino')
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 165 A deuoute salme of þe sautier which Lydegate daun Iohn translated in þe Chapell at Wyndesore at þe request of þe dean whyles þe Kyng was at evensonge
msItem.incipit: 165 O þowe my soule gif laude vn to þe lord / Blesse him and preyse and forgete him nought / Alle myne entraylles beoþe in deede and word / And al þat euer is in myn Inward thought
msItem.explicit: 171 Enseele oure qwytaunce with þy Redempcion / Whane þou shalt deeme vs stondyng afore þy face
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Benedic anima mea domino by Lidegate.
This is the second occurence of Lydgate's paraphrase of Psalm 102 in this manuscript; see also pp. 19-25.

msItem.title: 'Mumming for the Mercers of London'
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 171 And nowe filoweþe a letre made in wyse of balade by daun Johan brought by a poursuyaunt in wyse of Mommers desguysed tofore þe Mayre of London Eestfeld vpon þe twelffeþe night of Cristmasse ordeyned Ryallych by þe worthy Merciers Citeseyns of London
msItem.incipit: 172 Moost mighty lord Iubyter þe greet / Whos mansyoun is ouer þe sonnes beem / ffrome þens þat Phebus with his feruent heet / Reflecteþe his light vpon þe swyfft streeme
msItem.explicit: 175 To his presence er þat þey firþer flitte / Vnder supporte þat he wol hem admytte
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Desgysing made to Estfeld þane Mayre of London made by Lidegate.

msItem.title: 'Mumming for the Goldsmiths of London'
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 175 And nowe filoweþe a letre made in wyse of balade by ledegate daun Johan of a mommynge whiche þe Golde smythes of þe Cite of London mommed in Right fresshe and costelewelych desguysing to þeyre Mayre Eestfeld vpon Candelmasse day at nyght affter souper brought and presented vn to þe Mayre by an heraude cleped ffortune
msItem.incipit: 175 Þat worþy dauid which þat sloughe Golye / Þe first kyng þat sprang oute of Jesse / Of god echosen þe bookes specefye / By Samuel sette in his royal see
msItem.explicit: 178 Sette þees and rest welfare and vnytee / Duryng youre tyme thoroughe oute þis cytee
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margins: A desgysing to þe Mayre By þe Goldsmythes.

msItem.title: Life of St Margaret
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 178 And heere begynneþe þe Lyff of þe hooly virgyne seynte Margarete translated oute of þe legent in to oure englisshe tonge by Lidegate daune Johan þe Munk of Bury at þe Request of my lady of huntyngdon some tyme þe Countasse of þe March
msItem.incipit: 178 At þe Reuerence of saynte Margarete / My pourpos is hir lyf for to compyle / Þoughe þat I haue no Rethorykes swete / Nor colour noon tenbelisshe with my style
msItem.explicit: 195 But chaast gemme þy servantes sette at eese / And bee þeyre help in mescheef and diseese
msItem.note: Added title in the upper margins: Þe Lyff of Sainte Margarete Made by daun John Lidegate.

msItem.title: 'Criste qui lux es et dies'
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 195 Beholdeþe here and seeþe þe translacioun of þe ympne Criste qui lux es et dies by Lydegate in wyse of balade
msItem.incipit: 195 Criste qui lux es et dies - Cryst þat art booþe daye and light / And sooþefaaste sonne of al gladnesse / Þat doost awey derknesse of night / And souereyne light of al brightnesse
msItem.explicit: 197 for which wee sing in Ioye and woo / deo patri sit gloria
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Criste qui lux es et dies made by Lidegate.

msItem.title: Seven Penitential Psalms (variant version)
msItem.author: Thomas Brampton
msItem.rubric: 197 Loo heere begynnen þe sevene salmes translated oute of Latyne in to englisshe by an hooly and gret Clerk þat was reclused in þe west partie of England [added: whosse name was ffrater Thomas Bramptone saȝe Theologie doctor fratrum minorum pauperculus confessor de latino in Anglicum Anno domini MCCCCxiiii ad dei honorem et incrementum deuocionis]
msItem.incipit: 197 As I me lay alloone in bedde / And seeknesse refft me my rest / What maner lyffe þat I hade ledde / ffor to bethenke me thought it best
msItem.explicit: 233 And alle þat maake hir last eende / With Ne reminiscaris domine
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: þe seven Salmes Translated.

msItem.title: 'The Complaint of Christ to Man and Man's Answer'
msItem.rubric: 233 Takeþe heed of þis hooly balade conteyned vpon hooly writte made by a maystre of diuynite by duocyoun
msItem.incipit: 234 Þis is Crystes owen compleynt frome man to man he dere haþe bought / him self he seyþe til vs atteynt my lewed people what haue I wrought
msItem.explicit: 235 And Mary mylde swettest of face prey for wee beon fer byhynde / ffor weepe we may and sey allas By cause we beo toure lord vnkynde
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: þe complaynt of Cryst frome man to man.

msItem.title: The Thyrtty Days of the Mone [Storia Lune]
msItem.rubric: 235 And heere nowe filowing bigynneþe a weele compyled thing in wyse of deestynarye And of ouþer behoouely gouuernaunces touching þe goode tale of mannes heele studyed and laboured by gret philosofres and clerkes of olde tyme beholdeþe and reedeþe
msItem.incipit: 235 God þat al þis worlde haþe wrought / And al mankynde with his blood bought
msItem.explicit: 257 ffor as by doctryne þat haþe been taught / It is truwe ne douteþe it naught
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: A dyetarie for Mans heele.

msItem.title: Prognostics from the day on which Christmas falls
msItem.incipit: 257 But yit takeþe heede andyee shall here / A tale nye acordant to þis mater
msItem.explicit: 261 He gyve vs grace oure destenye be / To seo him in heven in his see
msItem.note: Added titles to the upper margins: A dyetarie ffor mans Governaunce.

msItem.title: Saying
msItem.incipit: 251 ffelix infelicitas: est non habere filios neque filias - pub. sapient.
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Secreta secretorum, translated into Latin by Philip of Tripoli
msItem.author: Pseudo-Aristotle
msItem.rubric: 261 Incipit liber Aristotelis de secretis secretorum siue de regimine principium vel Regum seu dominorum
msItem.incipit: 261 Domino suo excellentissimo in cultu religionis cristiane strenuissimo Guidoni de Valencia ciuitatis Tripoli
msItem.explicit: 337 Et cum tibi dant diuersa signa et aduersa declina semper ad meliorem et probabiliorem partem
msItem.finalRubric: 337 Completus est tractatus de signis et moribus naturalibus homini ad regem magnificum alexandrum qui dominatus fuit toti orbi dictusque monarcha in septentrione
msItem.note: Added title to the uper margins: Aristotles booke of þe Secrete of Secretis and Aristotle þe Secrete of Secretes.

msItem.title: 'A Sayenge of the Nyghtyngale'
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 337 Loo þus endeþe here þappistel of þe regiment of prynces þe whiche daun Aristotiles weel avised wrote vn to þe kyng Alexander and filowing nowe here nexst beginneþe a seying of þe Nightingale ymagyned and compyled by lydegate daun Johan þe Monk of Bury
msItem.incipit: 337 In Juygne whan Tytan was in þe Crabbes hed / Towardes even þe saphyre huwed sky
msItem.explicit: 348 As flour eerdeyned for to releeve man / Which bare þe frut þat sloughe our foo Sathan
msItem.finalRubric: 348 of þis balade daune John made no more
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: A devoute meditacion made by Lidegate of þe Nightyngale.

msItem.title: 'A Procession at Corpus Christi'
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 348 And nowe here foloweþe an ordenaunce of a processyoun of þe feste of corpus cristi made in londoun by daun John Lydegate
msItem.incipit: 349 Þis hye feste for to magnefye nowe / ffeste of festes mooste hevenly and devyne / In goostly gladnesse to governe vs and guye / By which al grace dooþe vppon vs shyne
msItem.explicit: 356 Of which god graunt eternal suffysaunce / where aungels sing everlasting Osanna
msItem.finalRubric: 356 Shirley kouþe fynde no more of þis Copye
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: An Processioun of Corpus Christi by Lidegate.

msItem.title: 'Lak of Stedfastnesse'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 356 Balade Royal made by oure laureal poete of Albyoun in hees laste yeeres
msItem.incipit: 356 Sume tyme þis worlde was so stedfast and stable / Þat mans worde was holde for obligacyoune
msItem.explicit: 357 Dreede god do lawe love trouth and worþynesse / And dryve þy people ageine to stidfastnesse
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balades by Chaucer Made.

msItem.title: 'Truth' or 'Balade de bon conseyl'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 357 Balade by Chaucier [added later: on his dethe bede]
msItem.incipit: 357 flee frome þe prees and dwelle with soþefastnesse / Suffice vn to þy goode þaughe it bee smal
msItem.explicit: 358 Weyve þy louste and let þy gooste þee lede / And trouth þee shal delyver owte of drede
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balades by Chaucer Made.

msItem.title: 'Gentilesse’
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 358 Balade by Chaucier
msItem.incipit: 358 Þe first fader fynder of gentylesse / What man desyreþe gentyl for to be / Mote filowe heos traces and alle heos wittes dresse / Vertue to suwe and vyces for to flee
msItem.explicit: 359 Þat makeþe heos heyres hem þat wel him qweeme / Al weyre þey mytre corone or dyadeeme
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balades by Chaucer Made.

msItem.title: Prayer for Christianity
msItem.incipit: 359 Dominus conservet papam et gregem / Reginum et Regem / Populum et legem / Et perducat nos ad ipsum
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balades by Chaucer Made.

msItem.title: Prayer for England
msItem.incipit: 359 Lord god preserve vnder þy mighty hande / Þe Kyng þe Qwene þeire peple and þis lande
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added title to the upper margins: Balades by Chaucer Made.

msItem.title: 'Of the Sodein Fal of Princes in oure Dayes'
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 359 Here folowen seven balades made by daun John Lydegate of þe sodeine fal of certain princes of ffrance and Englande nowe late in oure dayes
msItem.incipit: 359 Beholde þis gret prynce Edwarde þe secounde / Which of diuers landes lord was and Kyng / But so governed was he nowe vnderstonde / By suche as caused foule his vndoyng
msItem.explicit: 361 And his destrucioun if I shal not lye / ffor bouned he was and did in meschef dye
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: þe fale of Prynces.

msItem.title: Shirley's bookplate motto
msItem.author: John Shirley
msItem.rubric: 361 Balade
msItem.incipit: 361 Yee þat desyre in herte and haue plesaunce / Olde storyes in bokis for to rede / Gode matiers putte hem in remembraunce / And of oþer ne take yee none hede
msItem.explicit: 361 Whane yee þis boke haue over redde and seyne / To Johan Shirley restore yee it ageyne
msItem.note: Added note in the hand of John Stow (1524/5-1605): This John Shirley whis wyfs [?] was buryed in þe hospitall of seint bartelmeu by smythefyld and ther remaynethe a fayr monument of hym.

msItem.title: Troilus and Criseyde (extract)
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 361 Pandare to Troylus
msItem.incipit: 361 A whestone is no kerving instrument / And yitte it makeþe sharp kerving toolis / If þou wost ought where þat I haue miswent / Eschuwe þou þat for suche thing to þee scoole is
msItem.explicit: 361 If þowe do so þy witte is wele bewared / By his contrarie is every thing declared

listBibl.bibl: Furnivall, Odd Texts (1871), I, p. x.

msItem.title: Stanza
msItem.incipit: 361 Qui servit nequam mercedem non capit equam / Omnia qui querit perdere dignus erit
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: On Kissing at 'Verbum caro factum est'
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 362 A balade made by þe Munk of Bury Whiles it is seyde verbum caro factum est
msItem.incipit: 362 Ye devoute people whiche kepe an observaunce / Meekly in chirche to kisse stone or tree / Eerþe or yren kepeþe remembrance / What þey mene takeþe þe moralitee
msItem.explicit: 362 And ever haue mynde of cristes passioun / Which for þy sake wered þe crowne of thorne

msItem.title: 'A Complaint for my Lady of Gloucester and Holland'
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 363 Here bygynneþe a complaynte of a solitarye persone compleyning þabsence of þe moste renomed and best beloued pryncesse þat euer of hire estate in þeos dayes came in to þis Reaume of logres by þe weye of mariage and so sodeynly vnordynatly departed hens as hit is sayde and spouken in many Regyouns by þe hegheste estates þer
msItem.incipit: 367 A solytarye soore compleynyng / Sat weping by a water syde / Yeeris and dayes awayting / Which with goode hope dyd aye abyde
msItem.explicit: 367 Of hye and lowe to reken alle / Hir godsone after hire doþe calle
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Complaynte for þe departing Of my ladye of Holond.

Added note to the title in the hand of John Stow (1524/5-1605): wyffe to humfrey duke of glosestar / houre [?], þe sayd humfrey wngodly maryed, she beynge þe lawfull wyffe of John duke of brabaunte, and besyds her he all so kepte þe company of othar a mongste þe whiche was one Elianor Chobham, who by sorsere and withe craffe [sic], cawsyd hym to leave þe sayd Jaquyl of holand and to marie her þe sayd Elianowr, who afftar was a traytoresse to kynge henry þe vj.
The poem is followed by the following line: R. henricus Rex quintus is nott god be þe rodd.

msItem.title: 'Chaucer’s wordes unto Adam'
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.rubric: 367r Chauciers wordes Geffrey vn to Adame his owen cryveyne
msItem.incipit: 367r Adam scryveyne if euer it þe byfalle / Boece or Troylus for to wryten nuwe / Vnder þy long lokkes þowe most haue þe scalle / But affter my makyng þowe wryte more truwe
msItem.explicit: 367rIt to corect and eke to rubbe and scrape / And al is thorugh þy necglygence and rape

msItem.title: Extract from the Fall of Princes (Book 2, lines 4432-8)
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 368 A prouerbe
msItem.incipit: 368 Disceyte deceyueþe and shal beo deceyued / ffor by disceyte who þat is desceyvable / Þaughe heos disceytes beo not aperceyvable / To a desceyuous disceytes beon retournable
msItem.explicit: 368 ffor whoo with fraude þat fraudelent is founde / Til a defraudour fraude wol ay Rebounde

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: 368 Dampno quid peneris vuulnus quid vuulnere morbus / Quid morbo mors et quid morte nephandus amor
msItem.rubric: 368 videte
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Extract from the Fall of Princes (Book 3, Chapter 4)
msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.rubric: 368 Loo here my lordes begynneþe a balade ryal nowe late made by daun Johan Lydegate þe Munk of Bury ymagyned by him with in þe tyme of his translacioun of Bocas by þe commandement of my lord of Gloucestre
msItem.incipit: 368 Þis Tragedye gyveþe a gret warnyng / By clere ensaumples of manyfolde resoun
msItem.explicit: 370 Lyche to Syryns with voyce melodyous / Blaundisshe youre erys to make yowe lechcherous
msItem.note: Added title to the upper margins: Balade of Bochas.

msItem.title: List of Knights of the Order of the Garter
msItem.rubric: 371 Ista sunt nomina ordinis sancti Georgi de Gareterio Anno quo Sigismundus Rex Romanorum fuit in Anglia tempore Regis henrici - Quinti
msItem.incipit: 371 Rex Romanorum
msItem.explicit: 371 Dominus Willelmus Haryngtoun

msItem.title: Prayer to Christ attributed to a devout recluse
msItem.rubric: 372 O. ye reders beholdeþe here an holy prayer made by a devoute Recluse to be sayde anone affter þe levacioun of þe sacrament; whane þe preste is at masse
msItem.incipit: 372 Lord god almighty fader and sone and holy goste thre persones in trinite nd on god þat made al þis worlde o nought / by þe preest nowe mynistred vppoun þe awter verray god and man vnder þe forme of bred and wyne in flesshe and blode I beseche þee lord if it be þy wylle thorowe þys grace and mercy and mediacioun of þat moste gloryous virgyne oure lady sainte Mary of saint John þevangelist of saint Nycholas of saint Thomas of sainte Kateryne sainte Margarete and sainte Susanne of alle þe saintes in heven and þe holy folkes in eorþe þat I may pacyently with oute any gruching accepte and resceyve þe trybulaciouns of þis wreched worlde and lyve in þy lawe with suche contricioun confescioun and satisfaccioun clene oute of dette and dedly synne whanne I shall departe owte frome þis wey lyff and seo of þe parfyte noumbre of hem þat þow haste ordynde perpetuelly to þe everlasting blisse of heven / gode lord Cryst ihesu ffor þat peynful passyoun of deth þat þou suffredest on þe crosse in þe mounte of Calvary for þe redempcioun of al man kynde vppoun Gode Fryday - Adoramus te domine Jhesu Christe etcaetera - Amen - Adoramus te domine etcaetera
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added title to the upper margin: A devoute prayer.

msItem.title: A plea to his mistress
msItem.rubric: 373 Roundell
msItem.incipit: 373 ffresshest of colour and moste amyable / Consider þe my peyne and beoþe merciable
msItem.explicit: 373 þane letteþe þis compleynt \with mercy/ in your hert synk / Suffre þe not my trouþe to eonde [sic: DIMEV has "eoude"] þus gerdonlesse

msItem.title: Medical recipe for the stone (defective)
msItem.rubric: 373 Þis is medecyne parfite vse and proved by þe nobul duc of lancastre Johan for þe maladeye of þe stone
msItem.incipit: 373 Take saxifrage / Nettelsede / Comyn / Gromell sede / Annys . ffenelsede / parcell sede / smalache sede / folium cene / lycoris . Gingeber / drawe credere of eche one of þeos maters elyche muche / be it vnce of half let þe pacyent vse it ech wocke ones by [þe] morowe or ellis whane he goþe to bedde a spon[e] [...] shal not fayle by þe grace of gode by [...] þe pacient lette it / which [...] medel þe med[...]
msItem.note: Full transcription attempted; the rest of the recipe has gone lost with the remainder of the page.

supportDesc.support:
Pages 1-368 are Paper, folded in folio. Pages 2-32, 97-112, 145-352: Three-lobed mountain with cross.
Pages 33-96, 113-144 353-368: Bull's head with a septfoil .. followed by three parchment leaves, (pp. 379-374), the last one is fragmentary.

foliation.p: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

pp. [i]-[xii] are six unfoliated flyleaves at the beginning of the manuscript; pp. [xiii]-[xxiv] are six unfoliated flyleaves at the end of the manuscript; pp. [ia]-[id] are two paper pastedowns on p. [i]; pp. [v]-[viii] and [xv-xx] are five paper stubs; pp. [iii]-[iv] and [xxi-xxii] are two parchment stubs. Pages [ia]-[id], [i]-[ii], and [xxiii]-[xxiv] are modern paper flyleaves; and pp. [iii]-[xij] and [xiii]-[xxii] are original paper and parchment flyleaves.

signatures.p: The quires are numbered xiiij to xxxvi in the lower right-hand corner of their last versos although some of the numbers have been cropped off.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink in the lower right-hand corners of the last versos of quires.

supportDesc.condition: A loose paper slip is kept with the manuscript that contains handwritten notes on the manuscript's condition, recording torn, detached, or removed parts of pages, worm holes, and damage to the binding.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint (partially erased), frame only. Single columns except for pp. 82-86 which have 2 columns. 30-35 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: A poetic anthology copied in a cursive script with both secretary and anglicana features by the hand of the scribe John Shirley (?1366-1456)Shirley, John, 1366?-1456.

decoNote.p: Large (2 to 4 lines) initials in dark brown ink or outlines in dark brown ink featuring minor forms of decoration.
Cadels on the ascenders of letters written on the first lines and the descenders of letters written on the last lines of pages.

note.p: A summary description of the manuscript written in a 17th-century hand on two paper pastedowns on p. [i] (pp. [1a]-[1d]).
A title inscription in a 16th-century hand on p. [ix]: Lydgati opera quedam Anglie.

binding.p: Brown leather with blind- and gold-tooled frames and the armorial bookstamp of George Willmer (1582-1626) gold-stamped on the centres of the outside covers: his heraldic achievement consists of a coat of arms with a chevron between three eagles displayed, helmet esquire, crest out of a mural coronet with an eagle displayed, and motto (EXPERTVS CREDO) (see also 'Wilmer, George (1582 -1626)', in British Armorial Bindings).

origin.origDate: Copied between 1430 and 1432 by John Shirley (?1366-1456)Shirley, John, 1366?-1456, author, translator and scribe.
origin.p: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.3.20 was originally joined with London, Sion College Library, MS Arc.L.40.2/E.44, ff. 1-93, containing a copy of the Middle English The Pilgrimage of the Lyfe of the Manhode and London, British Library, Harley MS 78, ff. 80r-83v, containing Geoffrey Chaucer's 'Complaint unto Pity' and 'Complaint to His Lady'. These parts were also copied by John Shirley. For a reconstruction of the three manuscripts, see Connolly (1998), Table 2.

provenance.p: Owned by John Shirley (?1366-1456)Shirley, John, 1366?-1456, as is indicated by the presence of his bookplate poem. According to Connolly (1998), p. 95, Shirley used the manuscript as a source for compiling another anthology, now Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Ashmole 59.

An unknown London workshop active during the reign of King Edward IV used the manuscript as an exemplar for creating two anthologies of poems, now London, British Library, Additional MS 34360 and London, British Library, Harley MS 2251. Both of these manuscripts contain the work of the so-called 'Hammond scribe' (see Connolly (1998), p. 95).
Thomas Rychepe (fl. ?15th century) Rychepe, Thomas, fl. ?15th century: his name inscribed by a hand, possibly from the 15th century, on p. 29: Thomas rychepe.
John Richardson (fl. 16th century) Richardson, John, fl. 16th century: owned or access the manuscript: his name inscribed by a 16th-century hand on p. 93: per me Jhon Richard[...].

Barnwell (fl. 16th century) Barnwell, fl. 16th century: an unknown member of the Barnwell family owned or access the manuscript: inscription on p. 169 by a 16th-century hand referred to family members (Item for [?] Allyn Barnwell) and on p. 369 (John Barnwell was my ffather vnto thys).
John ?Tacker (fl. 16th century) ?Tacker, John, fl. 16th century: ownership inscription by a 16th-century hand on p. 367: iste liber pertenit ad me Johannem Tacker (now effaced).

John Stow (1524/5–1605) Stow, John, 1524/5–1605, historian: owned the manuscript in 1558, when he used it as a partial exemplar for London, British Library, Additional MS 29729, and annotated by him on pp. 25, 32, 33, 35, 36 [twice], 154, 158, 197, 361, and 365; Stow also added a stanza to the Life of St Margaret on p. 180 (see Connolly (1998), pp. 95-95, 101 n. 84).
George Willmer (1582-1626) Willmer, George, 1582-1626 of West Ham, Essex, Fellow of Trinity College: his armorial bookplate gold-stamped on the outsides of the front and rear covers.

history.acquisition: Donated to Trinity College by George Willmer (1582-1626) Willmer, George, 1582-1626 of West Ham, Essex, Fellow of Trinity College: the College's armorial bookplate pasted on the inside of the front cover together with inscriptions of its previous classmark R.9.14 [ink, crossed out] and current classmark: R.3.20 [pencil]; the classmarks R.3.19 [ink, crossed out] and R.3.20 [pencil] on p. [iii]; and its bookstamp in the lower margin of p. 1 and the upper margin of p. 372.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge: A Descriptive Catalogue, 4 vols (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1900–1904), pp. 75-82; Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995), pp. 22-23; and The Digital Index of Middle English Verse.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.
